Musical artist

Kendrick Lamar Duckworth (born June 17, 1987) is an American rapper and singer-songwriter. Known for his cinematic storytelling, melodic cadences, and artistic reinventions, he is regarded as one of the most influential artists of his generation, earning him the nickname "King Kendrick". He was named the second-greatest rapper of all time by Billboard and Vibe in 2023.

Duckworth started releasing music under the stage name K.Dot while he was attending high school. He signed with Top Dawg Entertainment in 2005, where he co-founded the hip hop supergroup Black Hippy. Following the success of his alternative rap debut album Section.80 (2011), Duckworth secured a joint contract with Aftermath Entertainment and Interscope Records. He rose to prominence with his gangsta rap-influenced second album Good Kid, M.A.A.D City (2012) and its top 40 singles "Swimming Pools (Drank)", "Poetic Justice" and "Bitch, Don't Kill My Vibe". It is the longest-charting hip hop studio album on the Billboard 200, spending over ten consecutive years on the chart.

Inspired by a visit to South Africa, Duckworth embraced jazz and G-funk styles on his third album, To Pimp a Butterfly (2015). It became his first of four consecutive number-one albums in the U.S., and is one of the most critically acclaimed albums of the 2010s decade. His collaboration with Taylor Swift on the remix of "Bad Blood" garnered his first number-one single on the Billboard Hot 100. Duckworth's critical and commercial success continued with his R&B and pop-leaning fourth album Damn (2017), yielding his second chart-topping single "Humble". He curated and executive produced the soundtrack album for the film Black Panther (2018), and departed from TDE with his double album Mr. Morale & the Big Steppers (2022); both projects broke various records.

Heralded as a generational icon by the California State Senate, Duckworth is the first non-classical or jazz artist to be awarded the Pulitzer Prize for Music. His accolades include 17 Grammy Awards (the third-most won by a rapper), a Primetime Emmy Award, a Brit Award, four American Music Awards, six Billboard Music Awards, 11 MTV Video Music Awards, and 29 BET Hip Hop Awards (the most won by any artist). He was named MTV's Hottest MC in the Game in 2012 and one of the 100 most influential people in the world by Time in 2016. Billboard named him one of the most successful artists of the 2010s decade and one of the greatest music video artists ever. Duckworth is one of the most-streamed rappers on Spotify, with all of his albums surpassing 1 billion streams each. Two of his concert tours, the Damn Tour (2017–2018) and the Big Steppers Tour (2022–2023), are amongst the highest-grossing rap tours in history. Three of his works were included in Rolling Stone's 2020 revision of the 500 greatest albums of all time. Outside of music, Duckworth co-founded the creative company PGLang and ventured into filmmaking with his creative partner, Dave Free. He has worked with various charities and advocates for racial equality and mental health awareness.

Life and career

Early life

Kendrick Lamar Duckworth was born on June 17, 1987, in Compton, California.[1][2] He is the first child of Kenneth "Kenny" Duckworth, a former gang hustler who previously worked at KFC,[3] and Paula Oliver, a hairdresser who previously worked at McDonald's.[3] Both of his parents are African Americans from the South Side of Chicago;[3] they relocated to Compton in 1984, when they were teenagers, due to his father's affiliation with the Gangster Disciples.[4] Duckworth was named after singer-songwriter Eddie Kendricks of the Temptations.[5] He was an only child until the age of seven and was described as a loner by his mother.[3][6] Eventually, his parents had his two younger brothers and younger sister, businesswoman Kayla Sawyer (née Duckworth).[7] His cousins include basketball player Nick Young and rapper Baby Keem.[8][9]

Duckworth and his family lived in Section 8 housing, was reliant on welfare and food stamps, and experienced homelessness.[10][11] Although he is not a member of a particular gang, he grew up with close affiliates of the Westside Pirus.[4] Despite suffering hardships, Duckworth remembered having "good memories" of his childhood that sparked his interest in hip hop music; such as sneaking into his parents' house parties.[3][12] He was raised secular, although he seldom attended church services and was taught the Bible by his grandmother.[13] He felt "spiritually unsatisfied" as a child due to the "empty" and "one-sided" nature of the sermons.[14]

After hearing a recording of his voice for the first time, Duckworth became interested in rapping.[15] He was introduced to police brutality after experiencing the first day of the 1992 Los Angeles riots.[3] When he was five years old, he witnessed his first murder while sitting outside of his apartment unit.[3] "It done something to me right then and there," Duckworth later admitted to NPR Music. "It let me know that this is not only something that I'm looking at, but it's something that maybe I have to get used to."[16] His parents nicknamed him "Man-Man" due to his precocious behavior, although he confessed it "put a stigma on the idea of me reacting as a kid sometimes—I would hurt myself and they would expect me not to cry."[17]

In school, Duckworth was a quiet and observant student who excelled academically and had a noticeable stutter.[18] His first grade teacher at Robert E. McNair Elementary School encouraged him to become a writer after she heard him correctly use the word "audacity".[19] As a seventh grade student at Vanguard Learning Center, Duckworth was introduced to poetry by his English teacher, Regis Inge.[20] He integrated the literary form into the curriculum as a response to the growing racial tensions amongst his students.[20] Through its connection to hip hop, he studied rhymes, metaphors and double entendres, which made him fall in love with songwriting: "You can put all your feelings down on a sheet of paper, and they'd make sense to you. I liked that."[3][20] Instead of completing assignments for other classes, Duckworth would scribe lyrics in his notebooks.[20] His initial writing was entirely profane, but it helped him manage his psychological trauma and depression; which he struggled with during his adolescence.[20][21] Inge played a vital role in his intellectual growth, often critiquing his lexicon and suggesting prompts to strengthen his prose.[20]

Duckworth later attended Centennial High School, where he failed physical education in the ninth grade.[22] He was enrolled in summer school during the tenth grade, which he dreaded because it forced him to be embroiled in a gang war.[22] Despite his efforts to avoid them, Duckworth soon became heavily involved with Compton's hedonistic gang culture, which led to numerous health scares and encounters with the police.[3] He distanced himself from the lifestyle following an intervention staged by his father.[6] When he was 16, he was baptized and converted to Christianity following the death of a friend.[23][24] Duckworth entered a lasting romantic relationship with his classmate, beautician Whitney Alford.[25] They experienced numerous difficulties within their relationship due to the former's sex addiction and repeated infidelity.[26] Duckworth graduated from high school in 2006 as a straight-A student.[27][28] He flirted with the idea of studying psychology and astronomy in college, but suspended his academic pursuits to focus on his music career.[3][29]

2003–2008: Career beginnings

During high school, Duckworth adopted the stage name K.Dot and began freestyling for his classmates.[1] His performances caught the attention of fellow student Dave Free, who traveled from Inglewood to watch him rap.[1] They quickly formed a friendship over their love of hip hop and the television sitcom Martin.[1] They recorded music together at Free's makeshift garage studio and at his older brother's Hyde Park apartment.[1] Duckworth's earliest performances were held at a "super hood" comedy club and behind of a tattoo parlor.[1] Free was his hype man during that time, while his older brother was his manager and disc jockey.[1] Duckworth recorded five mixtapes throughout the 2000s; his first, Youngest Head Nigga in Charge (Hub City Threat: Minor of the Year), was released during his senior year of high school.[b] The mixtapes primarily consisted of freestyles over the production of popular hip hop songs.[30]

In a series of retrospective reviews for Rolling Stone, Mosi Reeves complimented Duckworth's "unerring" sense of rhythm and timing found in Hub City Threat: Minor of the Year, but criticized his "overly beholden" flow and "clumsy" lyricism.[30] Free, who was working as a computer technician, introduced the mixtape to record producer Anthony "Top Dawg" Tiffith while attempting to repair his computer.[31] Tiffith was impressed with Duckworth's burgeoning abilities and invited him to partake in an audition process for entry into his newly established independent record label, Top Dawg Entertainment (TDE).[31] During his audition, Duckworth freestyled for Tiffith and record executive Terrence "Punch" Henderson for two hours; a strategy that impressed Henderson but bewildered Tiffith.[6][32] He was offered a recording contract from TDE in 2005, joining Jay Rock as the label's first signees.[6] Upon signing, he purchased a minority stake in the label for an undisclosed amount.[32]

Duckworth had a brief stint as a security guard when he started working on music with Jay Rock at TDE's in-house recording studio.[33][28] The bond he formed with him, Ab-Soul and Schoolboy Q led to the formation of the hip hop supergroup, Black Hippy.[34] In 2006, Duckworth signed an artist development deal with Def Jam Recordings and was featured on two singles by the Game. He also heavily contributed to Jay Rock's first two mixtapes, Watts Finest Vol. 1 and Watts Finest Vol. 2: The Nickerson Files.[17][35] Duckworth was ultimately let go from Def Jam after an encounter with its president and chief executive officer, Jay-Z; he later described it as "one of those situations where I wasn’t ready."[36][37] He released two projects in 2007: his second mixtape, Training Day, and a collaborative mixtape with Jay Rock titled No Sleep 'til NYC.[30] Reeves complimented Training Day's varied production and "well-executed" concept based on the 2001 film of the same name.[30] He described No Sleep 'til NYC as a "fun cypher session, nothing more, nothing less."[30]

2009–2011: Overly Dedicated and Section.80

Duckworth's third mixtape, C4 (2009), is a tribute project to Lil Wayne’s Tha Carter III (2008) and was supported by his co-sign.[38] Reeves felt that the mixtape was a "wrongheaded homage to a year-old, well-worn album."[30] From February to July, he toured with the Game on his LAX Tour as a hype man for Jay Rock.[39][40] Duckworth disliked how his stage name diverted attention away from his true identity, and decided to retire it.[41] He opted to use his first and middle names professionally and regards the name change as part of his career growth: "When people heard the name K.Dot, they were like, 'The kid is dope, he can rap; but who is he?' That went on for years—just another kid in the streets that can rap good, right? So I was like, 'Y'know what? I want people to know who I am as a person and what I represent.'"[42] For his eponymous debut extended play (2009),[43] Duckworth eschewed from the creative process of his mixtapes in favor of a project heavily focused on his songwriting over "lovely yet doleful" production.[30] Reeves described the EP as the "first standout project" of his career, praising its melancholic tone.[30] He felt that the project restored his reputation following the sting of criticism he received over C4.[30]

After striking a music publishing deal with Warner/Chappell Music,[44] Duckworth released his final mixtape, Overly Dedicated (2010), to digital retailers for the first time in his career.[45] He and Whitney Alford separated prior to its release.[46] Reeves described Overly Dedicated as a partial "victory lap" that marked a shift in his songwriting.[30] The mixtape peaked at number 72 on Billboard's Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums chart.[47] Duckworth served as Jay Rock's hype man for a second time during Tech N9ne's Independent Grind Tour, where Overly Dedicated was introduced to Dr. Dre.[48][49] After watching the music video for the song "Ignorance Is Bliss" on YouTube, he reached out to Duckworth with hopes of working with him and Snoop Dogg on his unfinished album, Detox.[48][50] He also considered signing him to his record label, Aftermath Entertainment, and was encouraged to by artists such as J. Cole.[51][52]

Duckworth entered a brief relationship with emcee Nitty Scott,[53][54] and was featured on XXL's 2011 Freshman Class list.[55] He released his debut studio album, Section.80, on July 2, 2011,[56] which was supported by its lead single "HiiiPower".[57] The album explored conscious and alternative hip hop styles and experimented with "stripped-down" jazz production.[58][59] Ogden Payne of Forbes considers it to be "the genesis to [Duckworth] successfully balancing social commentary with mass appeal."[60] Section.80 marked Duckworth's first appearance on the Billboard 200 chart, where it peaked at number 113. It sold approximately 5,000 copies in its first week of tracking, with minimal coverage from mainstream media outlets.[61]

To promote the album, Duckworth performed at small venues and college campuses across the U.S.[62][63] He was dubbed the "New King of the West Coast" by Snoop Dogg, Dr. Dre and the Game during a performance in West Los Angeles.[64][65] At the 2011 BET Hip Hop Awards, Section.80 was nominated for Best Mixtape. During the ceremony, Duckworth appeared alongside B.o.B, Tech N9ne, Machine Gun Kelly and Big K.R.I.T. in a cypher.[66] Throughout the year, he appeared on the Game's The R.E.D. Album, Tech N9ne's All 6's and 7's, 9th Wonder's The Wonder Years, and Drake's Take Care.[67]

2012–2013: Good Kid, M.A.A.D City and personal struggles

Duckworth began planning his second album before Section.80 was released.[68] From February to April 2012, he opened for Drake on his Club Paradise Tour.[69] He began working with J. Cole on a collaborative album around that time, but nothing came to fruition; Cole later admitted that the two "put it to bed years ago".[70][71] On March 8, The Fader reported that Duckworth had signed a joint venture recording contract with Aftermath Entertainment and Interscope Records; under the deal, TDE continued to serve as his primary label.[72] His first commercial single, "The Recipe" featuring Dr. Dre, premiered on rhythmic crossover radio on April 2.[73]

Good Kid, M.A.A.D City, Duckworth's second album, was formally announced on June 26, 2012, with a tentative release date of October 2.[74] Its lead single, "Swimming Pools (Drank)",[75] peaked at number 17 on the Billboard Hot 100, marking his first top 20 single in the U.S.[76] From September to October, he headlined the BET Music Matters Tour with Black Hippy and Stalley.[77] Duckworth won Lyricist of the Year at the 2012 BET Hip Hop Awards, where he performed a mashup and appeared in a cypher.[78] He was featured on ASAP Rocky’s single "Fuckin' Problems" alongside Drake and 2 Chainz, which reached the top 10 in the U.S.[79]

Experiencing a three-week delay, Good Kid, M.A.A.D City was ultimately released on October 22, 2012.[80] Duckworth worked with producers such as Pharrell Williams, Hit-Boy, Scoop DeVille, Jack Splash, and T-Minus to create an atmospheric West Coast hip hop album with heavy gangsta rap influences.[81] It was met with widespread critical acclaim, who lauded Duckworth's nonlinear songwriting and thematic scope. Greg Kot of the Chicago Tribune applauded him for giving gangsta tropes a "twist, or sometimes upend[ing] them completely" on a record that "brims with comedy, complexity and the many voices in [Duckworth’s] head."[82] Good Kid, M.A.A.D City debuted at number two on the Billboard 200, selling 242,000 copies.[83] It earned the highest first-week album sales of the year by a male rapper.[84] Its other singles, "Backseat Freestyle", "Poetic Justice", and "Bitch, Don’t Kill My Vibe", enjoyed moderate commercial success.[85][86] Good Kid, M.A.A.D City surpassed The Eminem Show (2002) to become the longest-charting hip hop studio album on the Billboard 200.[87] In October 2022, the album became the first hip hop studio album to spend over ten consecutive years on the Billboard 200.[88]

Duckworth and Whitney Alford rekindled their romantic relationship following the release of Good Kid, M.A.A.D City.[89] He promoted the album throughout 2013 by appearing on television programs and embarking on two concert tours: a national college tour with Steve Aoki and his first international headlining tour.[90][91] Duckworth struggled with depression, survivor's guilt and suicidal ideation during promotional events upon learning of the deaths of three close friends.[92] In an interview with MTV, he confessed that "psychologically, it messes your brain up. You live in this life, you know what I'm saying, but you still have to face realities of this. I gotta get back off that tour bus and go to these funerals."[93]

From October to December 2013, Duckworth opened for Kanye West on his Yeezus Tour, despite disapproval from his label and management team.[94][95] He was baptized for a second time during the beginning of the tour, and experienced a nervous breakdown near the end.[96][97] Duckworth won three awards during the 2013 BET Awards, where he performed a mashup of "M.A.A.D City" and "Bitch, Don’t Kill My Vibe" with Erykah Badu.[98][99] At the 2013 BET Hip Hop Awards. he performed a mashup of "Collard Greens" and "Money Trees" with Schoolboy Q and Jay Rock, and was featured in a TDE cypher.[100][101] Duckworth was named Rapper of the Year by GQ during their annual Men of the Year issue.[102] Following the issue's release, Tiffith pulled him from performing at GQ's accompanying party and accused Steve Marsh's profile on him of containing "racial overtones".[103][104]

Throughout 2013, Duckworth was featured on six songs: "YOLO" by the Lonely Island featuring Adam Levine that premiered during his first appearance as a musical guest on Saturday Night Live,[105] the remix of "How Many Drinks?" by Miguel,[106] "Collard Greens" by Schoolboy Q,[107] "Control" with Big Sean and Jay Electronica,[108] "Give It 2 U" by Robin Thicke featuring 2 Chainz,[109] and "Love Game" by Eminem.[110] His performance on "Control" was described as a “wake up call” for the hip hop industry; Rolling Stone noted that his verse made the track one of the most important hip hop songs of the last decade.[111]

2014–2016: To Pimp a Butterfly and Untitled Unmastered

After his opening stint for the Yeezus Tour ended, Duckworth started working on his third album.[95] He earned seven nominations at the 56th Annual Grammy Awards (January 2014), including Best New Artist, Best Rap Album, and Album of the Year for Good Kid, M.A.A.D City.[112] He was winless at the ceremony, which several media outlets felt was a snub.[113][114] Macklemore, who won Best New Artist and Best Rap Album, shared a text message that he sent Duckworth after the ceremony ended, in which he apologized for winning over him.[115] The incident was the subject of widespread media attention, controversy and Internet memes.[116] During the awards ceremony, Duckworth performed a mashup of "M.A.A.D City" and "Radioactive" with rock band Imagine Dragons, which was met with critical acclaim.[117][118]

Duckworth opened for Eminem on the Rapture Tour from February to July 2014.[119][120] On August 9, he premiered the short film M.A.A.D, which he starred in, commissioned and produced, during the Sundance Institute's Next Fest.[121] He released "I" as the lead single to his third album, To Pimp a Butterfly, on September 23, which won Best Rap Performance and Best Rap Song at the 57th Annual Grammy Awards.[122][123] His performance of "I" during his second appearance as a musical guest on Saturday Night Live was lauded by contemporary critics.[124] Duckworth was featured on three songs in 2014: "It's On Again" by Alicia Keys,[125] "Babylon" by SZA,[126] and "Never Catch Me" by Flying Lotus.[127] He won Lyricist of the Year for the second consecutive time at the 2014 BET Hip Hop Awards.[128]

Originally scheduled to arrive at a later date, To Pimp a Butterfly was released on March 15, 2015.[129] The album incorporated various genres synonymous with African American music, such as jazz, funk, and soul.[130] To capture its essence, Duckworth recruited producers such as Sounwave, Pharrell Williams, Terrace Martin, and Thundercat.[131] Alford contributed background vocals on select tracks.[132] Other singles from the album were "The Blacker the Berry",[133] "King Kunta",[134] "Alright", and "These Walls"–all of which enjoyed moderate commercial success.[135] Selling 324,000 copies in its first week, To Pimp a Butterfly became Duckworth's first number-one album on the Billboard 200 and set Spotify’s global first-day streaming record (9.6 million).[136][137] Billboard commented that "twenty years ago, a conscious rap record wouldn't have penetrated the mainstream in the way [Duckworth] did with To Pimp a Butterfly. His sense of timing is impeccable. In the midst of rampant cases of police brutality and racial tension across America, he spews raw, aggressive bard while possible cutting a rug."[138] Pitchfork noted that the album "forced critics to think deeply about music."[139]

In April 2015, Duckworth and Alford announced their engagement.[140][141] He earned his first number-one single on the Hot 100 through the remix of singer-songwriter Taylor Swift's "Bad Blood".[142][143] It won Video of the Year and Best Collaboration at the 2015 MTV Video Music Awards, while the music video for "Alright" won Best Direction.[144] Duckworth later re-recorded his featured appearance on the "Bad Blood" remix in support of Swift's counteraction to her 2019 masters dispute.[145][146] He opened the 2015 BET Awards with a controversial performance of "Alright" and won Best Male Hip Hop Artist.[147] He also won three awards at the 2015 BET Hip Hop Awards.[148] In support of To Pimp a Butterfly, Duckworth embarked on the Kunta's Groove Sessions Tour, which ran from October to November 2015 in select intimate venues across the U.S.[149] For his work on the album and other collaborations throughout the year, Duckworth earned 11 nominations at the 58th Annual Grammy Awards, the most by a rapper in a single night.[150] He led the winners with five awards: To Pimp a Butterfly was named Best Rap Album, "Alright" won Best Rap Performance and Best Rap Song, "These Walls" won Best Rap/Sung Performance, and "Bad Blood" won Best Music Video.[151]

During the ceremony, Duckworth performed a critically acclaimed medley of "The Blacker the Berry", "Alright", and an untitled song.[152] He revealed that the untitled track is from a "chamber of material" taken from the recording sessions of To Pimp a Butterfly that he was "in love with" but were not included on the album due to sample clearances and deadlines.[153] He previously performed untitled songs on The Colbert Report (December 2014) and The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon (January 2016).[154][155] After receiving a request from basketball player LeBron James to share the untitled works, Duckworth released his first compilation album, Untitled Unmastered, on March 4, 2016.[156] It contained eight untitled, dated, unfinished, and entirely self-written tracks that were intended to be included on To Pimp a Butterfly, and continued the album's exploration of jazz, funk, soul, and avant-garde styles.[157] Untitled Unmastered received critical acclaim and debuted atop the Billboard 200 with 178,000 album-equivalent units, becoming Duckworth's second consecutive number-one project.[158] Throughout the year, he was featured on four commercially successful songs: Beyoncé's "Freedom",[159] Maroon 5's "Don't Wanna Know",[160][161] the Weeknd's "Sidewalks",[162] and Travis Scott's "Goosebumps".[163]

2017–2018: Damn and Black Panther: The Album

Further information: Criticism of Spotify § 2017–18: Hate Content & Hateful Conduct policy

On March 1, 2017, during a joint cover story with Beck and Tom Waits for T: The New York Times Style Magazine, Duckworth confirmed that he was working on his fourth album.[164] He released the promotional single "The Heart Part 4" on March 23, before releasing the album's lead single "Humble" on March 30.[165][166] The song debuted at number two on the Hot 100 and reached the top spot in its second week of charting. It is Duckworth's second single, and first as a lead artist, to top the Hot 100.[167] His fourth album, Damn, was made available for pre-order on April 7, and was released on April 14.[168][169] Three days later, he headlined the first of two weekends of the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival.[170]

Damn utilized a more mainstream musical palette than To Pimp a Butterfly, exploring R&B and pop elements.[171] Production was primarily handled by Sounwave, DJ Dahi, Mike Will Made It, and Ricci Riera.[171] Rolling Stone described its sonics as a "brilliant combination of the timeless and the modern, the old school and the next-level."[172] Damn became Duckworth's most commercially successful album. It spent four nonconsecutive weeks atop the Billboard 200, marking his third consecutive number-one album, and debuted with 603,000 units sold.[173][174] All of the album's 14 songs debuted on the Hot 100, including the top-20 singles "Loyalty" and "Love". Duckworth is the fifth act in history to chart at least 14 concurrent titles on the Hot 100.[175] Damn was the seventh best-selling album of 2017 according to the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry, while "Humble" was the sixth best-selling single of the year.[176] By June 2018, it became the first album by a rapper or solo artist to have every song featured earn a gold certification or higher from the Recording Industry Association of America.[177][178]

To support Damn, Duckworth embarked on his first headlining arena tour, the Damn Tour, from July 2017 to July 2018.[179] It grossed $62.7 million revenue worldwide, becoming one of the highest-grossing hip hop tours in history.[180] At the 2017 MTV Video Music Awards, Duckworth opened the ceremony with a performance of "DNA" and "Humble".[181] He later won five awards, including Best Hip Hop Video, Best Direction, and Video of the Year for "Humble". Duckworth is the first artist to win Video of the Year for a video that they co-directed.[182][183] Throughout the year, he was featured on the remix to Future's "Mask Off",[184] SZA's "Doves in the Wind",[185][186] and Rich the Kid's "New Freezer".[187] He won Best Male Hip Hop Artist at the 2017 BET Awards,[188] while Damn won Favorite Rap/Hip Hop Album at the 2017 American Music Awards.[189] A collector's edition of the album, which featured its tracklist in reverse order, was released in December.[190][191]

On January 4, 2018, Duckworth and Tiffith announced that they would be curating and executive producing the soundtrack album for the superhero film Black Panther.[192] It was released on February 9 and was supported with three commercially successful singles: "All the Stars",[193] "King's Dead",[194] and "Pray for Me".[195][196] Duckworth contributed lead and background vocals to every track on the album, regardless of credit, and produced on select songs.[197][198] Music critics consider Black Panther: The Album to be a milestone achievement, giving praise towards its lyrics and cultural significance.[199][200] It spent two consecutive weeks atop the Billboard 200.[201] Duckworth opened the 60th Annual Grammy Awards performing a medley with rock band U2, featuring narration by Dave Chappelle.[202] He won five awards during ceremony: Damn was named Best Rap Album, "Humble" won Best Rap Performance, Best Rap Song, and Best Music Video and "Loyalty" won Best Rap/Sung Performance.[203]

Damn won the Pulitzer Prize for Music on April 16, 2018, marking the first time a musical composition outside of the classical and jazz genres received the honor. The Pulitzer jury praised the album as "a virtuosic song collection unified by its vernacular authenticity and rhythmic dynamism that offers affecting vignettes capturing the complexity of modern African American life."[204][205] From May to June, Duckworth co-headlined The Championship Tour with several TDE artists.[206][207] While on tour, he became embroiled in a public dispute with Tiffith and Spotify regarding the streaming service's Hate Content & Hateful Conduct policy.[208][209] Duckworth was featured on five songs in 2018: "Dedication" by Nipsey Hussle,[210][211] "Mona Lisa" by Lil Wayne,[212] "Tints" by Anderson .Paak,[213][214] and "Wow Freestyle" by Jay Rock; he also executive produced the latter's album Redemption.[215][216] At the 2018 American Music Awards, Black Panther: The Album won Favorite Rap/Hip-Hop Album.[217] Duckworth made his television acting debut as a drug addict in the crime drama series Power (2018).[218] His performance was acclaimed by critics, and earned him an NAACP Image Award nomination for Outstanding Guest Performance in a Comedy or Drama Series.[219][220][221]

2019–present: Fatherhood, TDE departure and Mr. Morale & the Big Steppers

After his two concert tours ended, Duckworth entered a four-year recording hiatus;[222] although he contributed to Beyoncé's The Lion King: The Gift, Schoolboy Q's Crash Talk, and Sir's Chasing Summer (all 2019).[223][224] He declined to perform at that year's Grammy and Academy Awards despite winning Best Rap Performance at the former ceremony and receiving a nomination for Best Original Song at the latter.[225][226] As his publishing deal with Warner/Chappell Music was beginning to expire,[44] he signed a long-term worldwide deal with Broadcast Music, Inc. in April.[227] Duckworth and Alford welcomed their daughter, Uzi, on July 26, 2019.[228][229] He continued to tour his work until November, after headlining the inaugural Day N Vegas music festival.[230] He had plans to tour in 2020, but they were cancelled due to the COVID-19 pandemic.[231]

On March 5, 2020, Duckworth and Dave Free launched the creative entity PGLang, which was described at the time as a multilingual, artist-friendly service company.[232][233] In October, he signed a worldwide administration agreement with Universal Music Publishing Group.[234] Duckworth announced through an August 2021 blog post that he was in the process of producing his final album under TDE; confirming rumors that emerged last year that he would be leaving to focus on PGLang.[235][236] The following week, he appeared on Baby Keem's single "Family Ties", which won Best Rap Performance at the 64th Annual Grammy Awards.[237][238] He made additional contributions to his album The Melodic Blue by providing background vocals on a select track and appearing on the song "Range Brothers".[239] In November, Duckworth held a "theatrical exhibition of his musical eras" during his second headlining performance at Day N Vegas,[240][241] and featured on Terrace Martin's album Drones.[242] He co-headlined the Super Bowl LVI halftime show alongside Dr. Dre, Snoop Dogg, Eminem, 50 Cent, and Mary J. Blige on February 13, 2022, which won the Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Variety Special (Live).[243][244]

After releasing the promotional single "The Heart Part 5",[245][246] Duckworth's fifth album, Mr. Morale & the Big Steppers, was released on May 13, 2022.[247] He and Alford used the album's cover art to reveal the birth of their son, Enoch.[248][249] The double album drew on jazz, R&B, trap, and soul influences;[250][251] Alford served as its primary narrator.[252] It was widely acclaimed by critics, who applauded Duckworth's vulnerable songwriting and scope.[253] Every track from the album charted on the Hot 100; its three singles–"N95", "Silent Hill", and "Die Hard"–debuted in the top-10.[254] Selling 295,000 units in its first week, Mr. Morale & the Big Steppers became Duckworth's fourth consecutive number-one album on the Billboard 200.[255] It later became the first hip hop album of 2022 to reach one billion streams on Spotify.[256] In support of Mr. Morale & the Big Steppers, Duckworth embarked on the Big Steppers Tour, which ran from July 2022 to December 2023.[257] The tour grossed $110.9 million in worldwide revenue, becoming the highest-grossing rap tour ever at the time.[c][259] Duckworth wrote, co-directed, and executive produced the short film adaptation of the song "We Cry Together", which was released worldwide in September 2022.[260] An accompanying concert film for the tour, Kendrick Lamar Live: The Big Steppers Tour, was released in November 2022.[261][262]

Duckworth won Favorite Male Hip Hop Artist at the 2022 American Music Awards, and Favorite Hip Hop Album for Mr. Morale & the Big Steppers. He received six awards at the 2022 BET Hip Hop Awards, including Album of the Year.[263][264] At the 65th Annual Grammy Awards (February 2023), Mr. Morale & the Big Steppers was named Best Rap Album, while "The Heart Part 5" won Best Rap Performance and Best Rap Song.[265] In May, Duckworth was featured on the standalone version of Beyoncé's single "America Has a Problem" and appeared on Baby Keem's single "The Hillbillies".[266][267] He won four awards at the 2023 BET Hip Hop Awards, and set four records in the process.[268] Duckworth was featured in the documentary concert film Renaissance: A Film by Beyoncé and executive produced Baby Keem's short film adaptation of The Melodic Blue.[269][270] Outside of music, he signed on to produce a comedy feature film with Free, Trey Parker and Matt Stone for Paramount Pictures.[271]

Artistry

Influences

"I was 8 years old when I first saw you. I couldn't describe how I felt at that moment. So many emotions. Full of excitement. Full of joy and eagerness. 20 years later, I understand exactly what that feeling was: inspired. The people that you touched on that small intersection changed lives forever. I told myself I wanted to be a voice for man one day. Whoever knew I was speaking out loud for you to listen."

—Duckworth to Tupac Shakur on the 19th anniversary of his death[272]

Tupac Shakur is Duckworth's biggest influence, having impacted both his professional and personal lives.[273] One of his earliest childhood memories is watching him and Dr. Dre film the second music video for their single "California Love" with his father at the Compton Swap Meet.[12] Duckworth has described himself as an "offspring" of Shakur's artistry and sociopolitical views.[274] Although some publications regard him as the Shakur of his generation,[275][276] he strives to maintain his individuality.[277]

Shakur's The Don Killuminati: The 7 Day Theory (1996), The Notorious B.I.G.'s Life After Death (1997), and DMX's It's Dark and Hell is Hot (1998) influenced Duckworth's artistic direction: "I don't look at these albums like just music; it sounds like an actual film."[278] He also listened and took influence from Mos Def and Snoop Dogg during his childhood,[279] and said, "I wouldn't be here today if it wasn't for Eazy-E."[280] 50 Cent's mixtape success inspired Duckworth to become an independent artist,[6] while his view on being categorized as a conscious rapper, "Yeah, I'm a conscious artist because I have a conscience," gave him a sense of perspective.[281]

Prodigy of Mobb Deep was a key influence on Duckworth's earlier mixtapes,[282] while his rapping technique was stemmed from Lil Wayne and his longevity.[283] Eminem and his album The Marshall Mathers LP (2000) introduced him to songwriting elements, such as ad-libs, and impacted his aggressive approach to records such as "Backseat Freestyle".[284][285][286] He took inspiration from N.W.A's tenacity of representing his hometown with "courage, honesty and artistic brilliance."[287] Various R&B and soul artists, including Marvin Gaye,[288] the Isley Brothers,[288] Michael Jackson,[289] Teddy Pendergrass,[290] Sade, and Anita Baker, have influenced Duckworth.[291] He performed with Prince, who impacted his vocal register,[292] at Paisley Park to celebrate the release of the latter's 2014 albums Plectrumelectrum and Art Official Age, which GQ described as "five minutes of brilliant insanity."[293] To Pimp a Butterfly was influenced by the works of jazz trumpeter Miles Davis and funk collective Parliament-Funkadelic.[294]

Musical style

The nature of Duckworth's musical style has been described as "anti-flamboyant, interior and complex."[295] He is rooted in West Coast hip hop,[296] and has continually reinvented his sound by branching out into other genres.[297] Due to his contributions to its audience growth, through his appeal to mainstream listeners, music critics generally categorize Duckworth as a progressive rap artist.[298] He suggests that his music is genreless, explaining in a 2012 interview, "You really can't categorize my music, it's human music."[299] PopDust opined that during the 2010s, a decade that was arguably defined by hip hop, Duckworth constantly pushed the boundaries of what the genre could be.[300]

Duckworth did not care for music production during the beginning of his career.[301] However, as he placed an emphasis on songwriting and "making material that's universal", he grew more exacting and adventurous with his compositions.[301] He is heavily involved with every aspect of his production process, including the mixing and mastering stages, and is known for working long hours in the recording studio.[302] "You gotta be hands on and know the different sounds and frequencies," Duckworth explained to Variety.[301] "What makes people move, what melodies stick with you, taking the higher octaves and the lower octaves and learning how to intertwine that in a certain frequency, how to manipulate sound to your advantage."[301] Duckworth chooses to work with a close-knit team of musicians, rather than constantly seek high-profile talent.[48] He has been working with his longtime producer, Sounwave, since his 2009 self-titled EP.[30]

Kendrick Lamar marked a pivotal change in Duckworth's artistry. Unlike his earlier mixtapes, which consisted of freestyles over CHR and urban radio singles, the EP incorporated melancholic and "doleful" original production that emphasized his lyrics.[30] Austere jazz production was blended with alternative rap styles on Section.80,[303] with instrumentals drawing from R&B, boom bap, psychedelia, and downtempo.[304] Good Kid, M.A.A.D City abandoned the tastes of contemporary hip hop by exploring a subtle, atmospheric side of West Coast hip hop and gangsta rap.[305][306] To Pimp a Butterfly is an amalgamation of genres synonymous with African-American music, most prominently jazz, funk, and soul.[307][308] It redefined jazz rap by highlighting improvisation and soloing rather than primarily using sampling.[309][310] Minimalist arrangements are incorporated in Damn and Mr. Morale & the Big Steppers.[311][312] Damn appealed to mainstream listeners through its pop and R&B-influenced production,[313] while the scattered and distorted instrumentals of Mr. Morale & the Big Steppers was designed to make listeners feel anxious and uncomfortable.[314]

Voice

Several media outlets consider Duckworth to be the greatest and most important rapper of his generation.[315][316] Billboard and Vibe named him the second-greatest rapper of all time, behind Jay-Z.[317] Described as a "blazing" technical rapper and "relentless searcher" by The New York Times,[295] Duckworth's "limber, dexterous" flow switches from derivative to generative metrics,[318][319] while incorporating internal and multisyllabic rhyme schemes.[320] His rhymes are typically manipulated within common time, allowing him to subtly control his metrical phonology and suggest formal ambiguities similar to pop and rock repertoires.[320] Some of his rhyme manipulations feature "flexible" new school styles evoking the 1990s, while others use "rigid" old school elements recalling the 1980s.[320] Duckworth frequently uses syncopation in his melodies to create contradictions between his lyrical content and rhythms.[321] With Good Kid, M.A.A.D City, he liberally plays with pronunciation, inflections, and delivery to mirror the album's emotional range.[322] Swing is used throughout To Pimp a Butterfly in a nod to the performance methods of jazz musicians.[323]

Duckworth possesses a versatile tenor vocal range,[324][325] and a raspy, half-shout timbre; where "his throat sounds dry and his mouth sounds wet."[326] André 3000 was the first rapper that introduced him to singing sensibilities in hip hop,[327] and he writes melody-driven songs as practice for his rap albums.[327] Duckworth became comfortable with his vocals over time, to the point where he feels confident enough to create singing-based albums.[328] Pitchfork noticed how his harmonies on To Pimp a Butterfly never made him sound alone throughout his "desolate" performance; comparing his vocal layering to "standing in the middle, unnoticed, of a large quarrelsome crowd."[329]

Praised for his willingness to use his voice as an instrument,[330] Duckworth adopts different cadences, tones, modulations, and timbres to suggest conflicting personalities, paint distinct emotions, and communicate stories using characters and personas.[331][332] His falsetto register, which he calls the "ghetto falsetto",[327] has been likened to Curtis Mayfield's.[333] MTV writes that by manipulating his voice, Duckworth calls back to a lineage that runs through James Brown's foundational work in the 1960s, 1970s psychedelia, Prince's "sweaty" phantasmagoria in the 1980s, and 1990s gangsta rap.[334] He was ranked the tenth-best solo singer of the 21st century by The Times in 2023.[335]

Songwriting

Further information: List of songs recorded by Kendrick Lamar

Branded as a "master of storytelling" by The New Yorker,[332] Duckworth has been referred to as one of the greatest lyricists in modern hip hop by several publications and his peers.[336][337] Pharrell Williams suggests that what makes his songwriting stand out is because he "knows how to be very disciplined with a subject matter, he knows that stickiness is important, and he knows that it has to be great."[338] American Songwriter notes that for as much as Duckworth is a musician, lyricist, and emcee, he is also "a playwright, a novelist, a short story author. He's literary within the art form of music."[339] Duckworth's reflective narrative songwriting pulls from a wide range of literary and cinematic techniques, such as hip hop skits and voice-overs, to allow his audience to follow internal and external storylines.[340] His fusion of various film styles and his sonic influence has elevated his works to be some of the most "consistently poignant" in hip hop, and promoted the advancement of the narrative device.[340]

Duckworth, who self-identifies as a musician and writer,[164] begins his songwriting process with an assortment of premeditated thoughts that he jotted down over the course of one year.[341] His personal experiences are a common source of inspiration, but he also pulls ideas from meeting new people, traveling, and experiencing different cultures.[341] A devout Christian, he additionally shares his spiritual triumphs and struggles on his songs.[342][343] He is an avid note-taker, and has developed keywords, phrases, and sounds to help him "trigger the exact emotions" he felt when writing the initial demo.[341]

Considered to be a "radio-friendly but overtly political rapper" by Pitchfork,[344] and a populist by The Wall Street Journal,[345] Duckworth's songwriting regularly infuses political criticism and social commentary concerning African-American culture.[346] Common themes explored include racial inequality, institutional discrimination, and black empowerment.[347] Duckworth's critiques has been compared to the State of the Union Address by The Guardian,[348] while Billboard described it as "Shakespearean".[349] HuffPost opined that his work is a "great" piece of journalism because it "speaks from the prerogative of black communities facing oppression and directly attacks the institutions responsible for their pain," an achievement most reporters cannot attain.[350]

Duckworth tries to carry a conceptual idea inside of his music, "whether it's a big concept or it's so subtle you can't even tell until you get to 20 listens."[301] Fans and publications have theorized that his albums are related to different forms of mass media.[351] Section.80 is regarded as a short story collection inspired and themed around events that impacted the millennial generation, such as Ronald Reagan's presidency.[352][353] The nonlinear narrative structure of Good Kid, M.A.A.D City is billed as a coming-of-age short film that chronicles Duckworth's harsh teenage experiences in his native Compton.[354][355] Its cinematic scope has been compared to the screenplays written by Martin Scorsese and Quentin Tarantino.[356][357] To Pimp a Butterfly unfolds as both a poem and blank letter that explores the responsibilities of being a role model and documents life as an African American during Barack Obama's presidency.[358][359] Damn is labeled as an introspective satire that explores the dualities of human nature and morality.[360][361] Mr. Morale & the Big Steppers takes on the form of a theatrical play, with confessional lyrics based on Duckworth's experiences in therapy.[362][363] Duckworth has won the BET Hip Hop Award for Lyricist of the Year nine times, the most wins by any artist.[364] He has also published articles for Billboard,[365] Interview,[366] Paper,[367] and XXL.[368]

Reception

Legacy

As one of the most influential musicians of the 2010s decade, Duckworth has been deemed a paradigm shift in contemporary hip hop and popular culture.[369][370] His discography became a catalyst in the upsurge of social consciousness across multiple generations; challenging the status quo by encouraging listeners to reexamine social institutions.[371] Throughout the Black Lives Matter movement and events following the 2016 U.S. presidential election, his work has been used as protest anthems.[372] According to American studies and media scholar William Hoynes, Duckworth's progressive elements places him amongst other African American artists and activists who "worked both inside and outside of the mainstream to advance a counterculture that opposes the racist stereotypes being propagated in white-owned media and culture."[373] He has been credited with reviving jazz rap and the music video as a form of social commentary.[374][375]

Duckworth's music has consistently garnered critical acclaim and commercial success, a rare combination in the music industry, as well as support from artists who have paved the way for his advancement.[376] His Pulitzer Prize win was considered a sign of the American cultural elite formally recognizing hip hop as a "legitimate artistic medium".[377] Senior artists such as Nas,[378] Eminem,[379] Dr. Dre,[380] Prince,[381] and Madonna have praised his musicianship.[382] David Bowie's final album, Blackstar (2016), was inspired by To Pimp a Butterfly, and its producer Tony Visconti praised Duckworth as a "rulebreaker" in the music industry.[383][384] Pharrell Williams called him "one of the greatest writers of our times" and likened him to Bob Dylan.[385] Duckworth has also been cited as a strong influence on the works of various modern artists,[386] including BTS,[387] Dua Lipa,[388] Tyler, the Creator,[389] Roddy Ricch,[390] and Rosalía.[391] Lorde regards him as "the most popular and influential artist in modern music."[392]

Public image

Despite becoming a prominent figure in popular culture, publications have noted Duckworth's unconventional approach to celebrity culture.[393] He is notoriously reserved; reluctant to publicly discuss his personal life and generally avoids using social media.[394][395] He is also decisive when engaging with mainstream media outlets, although journalists have complimented his "Zen-like" calmness and down to earth personality.[396][397] According to Duckworth, he has become "so invested in who I am outside of being famous, sometimes that's all I know. I've always been a person that really didn't dive too headfirst into wanting and needing attention. I mean, we all love attention, but for me, I don't necessarily adore it."[398] His lyrics have been a topic of media scrutiny, leading to both praise and controversy.[16][399][400] He has also been involved in alleged feuds with several rappers throughout his career, which have received consistent press coverage.[401][402][403]

Following the release of Good Kid, M.A.A.D City, media outlets have described Duckworth as the "modern hip hop messiah".[404] Some critics dislike his "grating" political infusions,[405] causing him to be viewed as having a savior complex.[406] He uses his music to critique and deconstruct his attributed perception; on Section.80, he raps, "I'm not the next pop star, I'm not the next socially aware rapper / I am a human motherfucking being over dope-ass instrumentation."[407] However, Duckworth has declared himself to be the "greatest rapper alive" due to his personal connection to hip hop.[408] "I'm not doing it to have a good song, or one good rap, or a good hook, or a good bridge," he explained to Zane Lowe. "I want to keep doing it every time, period. And to do it every time, you have to challenge yourself and you have to confirm to yourself—not anybody else, confirm to yourself that you're the best, period. [...] That's my drive and that's my hunger, I will always have."[409]

Business ventures

Duckworth has been described as an "authentic" businessman who takes "calculated steps to establish his brand from the ground-up" and leaves nothing to chance.[410] He approaches traditional album rollouts with an unorthodox method, using creative Easter eggs and leaving cryptic messages.[411] Before releasing a studio album, Duckworth shares a promotional single taken from "The Heart", a timestamp song series designed to "observe the beating pulse behind his music."[412] The vulnerable themes explored on the non-album singles have strengthened his relationship with his "inquisitive" fanbase known as Kenfolk.[412][413]

Duckworth has partnered with several businesses. He crafted an original song with record producer Nosaj Thing to promote Microsoft's Windows Phone in 2011.[414] He starred alongside DJ Calvin Harris and singer Ellie Goulding in a marketing campaign for Bacardi in 2014.[415] As a minority shareholder of TDE, Duckworth was set to serve as the executive producer for the label's film division.[32] He partnered with American Express on advertising campaigns for Art Basel and Small Business Saturday.[416] Duckworth designed sneakers with Reebok and Nike as a brand ambassador for both companies.[417][418] He is an angel investor of the music creation platform EngineEars.[419]

Advocacy and philanthropy

A supporter of the Black Lives Matter movement, Duckworth is a vocal advocate for racial equality.[420] He supported Frank Ocean when he came out via an open letter.[421] After questioning the importance of voting, Duckworth endorsed Barack Obama's presidential re-election campaign.[422][423] He had a "humanizing" meeting with Obama in 2015, which was documented in a public service announcement in support of MENTOR: The National Mentoring Partnership and My Brother's Keeper Challenge.[424] Duckworth is also an advocate for mental health awareness,[425] and has used his music to promote self-love and other mental health initiatives.[426] He strongly dislikes Donald Trump and persistent conversations regarding him, believing it to be like "beating a dead horse".[427][428] He was critical of the U.S. Supreme Court's landmark decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.[429]

Duckworth has headlined charity concerts benefitting local and international non-profit organizations.[430][431] He donated to the American Red Cross in November 2012 to support victims of Hurricane Sandy.[432] In December 2013, Duckworth donated $50,000 to his alma mater, Centennial High School, in support of its music department.[433] He embarked on a small concert tour in 2014, and donated all of the revenue to Habitat for Humanity and his hometown.[434] In July 2017, Duckworth purchased a wheelchair-accessible van for a quadriplegic fan.[435][436] He has regularly performed at TDE's annual holiday toy drive at Nickerson Gardens,[437][438] and organizes his own toy drive in Compton.[439] In June 2020, he joined a peace walk to protest against the murders of George Floyd and Breonna Taylor.[440][441]

Achievements

Further information: List of awards and nominations received by Kendrick Lamar

Throughout his career, Duckworth has won 17 Grammy Awards (the third-most by a rapper in history),[442][443] a Primetime Emmy Award,[444] four American Music Awards,[445] 29 BET Hip Hop Awards (the most won by any artist),[446] 11 MTV Video Music Awards (including two Video of the Year wins),[447] 6 Billboard Music Awards,[448] and a Brit Award.[449] As a songwriter, he has received nominations for an Academy Award and a Golden Globe Award.[450][451] At the 58th Annual Grammy Awards, Duckworth received the most Grammy nominations by a rapper in one night, with 11.[452][150] During the 65th ceremony, he became the first artist from any genre to be nominated for Album of the Year with four consecutive lead studio albums since Billy Joel (1979–1983).[453]

Duckworth has appeared in various power listings. In 2015, he was featured on Ebony's Power 100 list that honors leaders within the African American community.[454] Time included him on its annual list of the 100 most influential people in the world in 2016.[455] He has appeared on Forbes' Celebrity 100 ranking (2019),[456] and its 30 Under 30 list twice in the music category (2014 and 2018).[457][458] Duckworth was included twice in Billboard's lists of the greatest rappers of all time (2015 and 2023).[459][460] Complex named him the best rapper alive twice (2013 and 2017),[461][462] and included him in their list of the 20 best rappers in their 20s thrice (2013, 2015, and 2016).[463] In May 2015, Duckworth was declared a generational icon by the California State Senate for his contributions to music and philanthropy.[464] He later served as a grand marshal for the Compton Christmas Parade,[465] and was presented with the key to the city of his hometown for representing its evolution.[371]

Good Kid, M.A.A.D City, To Pimp a Butterfly, and Damn were featured in Rolling Stone's industry-voted ranking of the 500 greatest albums of all time and the 200 greatest hip hop albums of all time.[466][467] Good Kid, M.A.A.D City was additionally featured in the magazine's list of the 100 best debut albums of all time, and was named the greatest concept album ever.[468][469] To Pimp a Butterfly was ranked by several publications as one of the greatest albums of the 2010s decade.[470] Damn is the recipient of the 2018 Pulitzer Prize for Music, the first time a musical work outside of the classical and jazz genres was honored.[471][472] Its tour companion, along with Big Steppers Tour (2022–2023), are two of the highest-grossing hip hop tours of all time.[473]
